pros: non corporate, very dedicated to their mission; easier to know what meds covered given only a few insurance plans; i have only respect for this organization as they are not in it to make money; patients very respectful and staff like family; lots of opportunities for leadership
cons: referral process a bit cumbersome given had to log onto to different system but this may have changed; benefits

pros: Full Benefits, including 401K, dental, health, and life insurance
cons: You have to work for at least a year to be able to enroll in 401K

job_title: Case Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good for young professionals to get more experience. Helps connect people to the community. Supporting patients makes the job worth it, but it can lead to burnout quickly because you get ZERO support from management.
cons: The management is entitled & the most hierarchical place I have ever worked under. I would constantly hear “if I have to pull ranks I will” & the management would make employees feel inferior. The pay is really low for San Francisco, most case managers in the area make around $30 or more per hour. If you ever get a raise, (I got one and it was around a .25 cent increase), they tell you not to tell your coworkers or mention your wages, which is illegal because you have a right to discuss your salary. Only some departments have unions, but some managers would discourage that other departments try to unionize. The staff have historically gone on strike and would protest to management to increase their wages and that same discussion continues to this day. They provide minimum training and it feels so isolating because you get no support when you have a question or need more staff to support a patient.

job_title: Staff RN in San Francisco, CA
pros: Select staff are committed to working and improving the clinic and patient experience.
cons: Staff are overworked. High and constant turnover. Some staff leave disgruntled or act inappropriately in front of upper management and continue to work for the organization without repercussions. C suite has limited knowledge on what happens in clinic as their main objective is increasing their patient count while not providing appropriate trainings for their staff. Pay is low as others have mentioned and I was also told not to discuss wages with coworkers (illegal).

review_title: Great Mission Statement and medical staff

personally gratifying

lower pay

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Co-workers are caring, compassionate, and dedicated to the patients
cons: Pay is low, management is asleep, and they keep pilling on the work for no extra pay.

job_title: Behavioral Health Clinician in San Francisco, CA
cons: Horrible management and supervisor never gave support. Productivity is the main focus with an expected busy workload. BBS hours did not matter, and it was refused to get signed. It was expected to service 25-30 patients, and as an associate, only ten hours counted out of all the patients seen in a week. No mental support and supervisor was always on vacation, meaning hours were not valid during that Week of absence and the associate was expected to handle the work independently. The supervisor had a power struggle and made sure that everyone recognized the power.

review_title: Great patients, a lot of work, low pay
pros: It is Gratifying to care for this population. And they are appreciative. Pathology is varied and abundant
cons: Low pay, especially considering the high volume. Over 30 years, the mentality of administration on this issue has not changed

job_title: Community Outreach Supervisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you are eager to learn and get involved, then there is no shortage of work for you and lots of new skills to learn.
cons: Financially, the clinic does not equitably compensate its staff. There is a clear gap between staff that work the day-to-day and the Director/Executive teams
